text: Only fatal flaw in my opinion with this laptop, that I found, (which includes all of the late model Thinkpads) is the relocation of the CTRL and FN keys. There was no reason to swap those keys. For those of us that also have company PCs or docking stations with regular keyboards docked, it‚Äôs a total pain to have to consciously remember when switching between the two. The Ideapads don‚Äôt do this and neither does any other manufacturer. They took one of the best keyboards in the industry and messed it up in one fell swoop.
author: Tank M

text: It's really too bad that Lenovo is still unable to use decent trackpads in their laptops. I've been a longterm Thinkpad user myself and still am, i grew up with the trackpoint as well but nostalgia doesn't make that thing any better than the shitty, outdated pointing device that it is. It's just there, because trackpads used to be even shittier and in lenovos case they unfortunately still are. Use a great trackpad with decent palm recognition for a while (aka. Razer Blade Stealth, MBP, Surface Book,...)and you won't shed a tear for this red little pimple whose only purpose (imho) it is to leave a dull spot on your screen if you carry it around a lot. Yes I know you can take it off but then theres this empty spot with the plastic holder which just looks like something has broken off. It's like picking between cancer in the left or the right testicle. Ok, I'm done ranting. Now, I shall be stoned....*grabspipe* xD

text:
How on earth is 720p video not good enough for conference calls...?  The picture is clear and literally far higher resolution than the box your face will be occupying on the screen of whoever's calling you...  Even if you're fullscreen, why on earth is like 4K ultra HD video necessary for... for conference calls?

I'm literally watching this video fullscreen on a work's laptop with a 1080p resolution, fullscreen and like... the video at 5:48 is crystal fucking clear...  1366x768 isn't even an uncommon resolution on in service laptops to this day, and, again, you're rarely going to be full screen anyway....

As for the audio quality, you clearly have noise reduction enabled which is what gives it the "in a box" audio effect, and this effect is usually enabled by default on work machines to block out the sound of background chatter.  If you turned it off you'd probably have pretty good audio quality too.
author: Muzikman127

text:
I get this is maybe not the habit of most consumers, but for from my point of view:laptop speakers are always going to be shitty. The nature of what a laptop is and how it's built means that, at best, you're going to have some speakers that are completely shitty for music and just about passable for movies/TV.

For that reason, I pretty much always use a laptop either with headphones, or, more likely, a bluetooth speaker like a JBL flip 3 (or even a clip 2 which is tiny and mono and cheap but still miles better than literally any laptop speaker on the market)

I'd say, if you're going to watch movies (or especially if you're going to listen to music), spend 40-100$ on a small bluetooth speaker, and don't let the quality of the inbuilt speaker be a factor in your laptop choice...

text:
I don't get it: Why do you need a good camera for conference calls?
You are not trying to show tiny details of a just-produced part during a conference call, right? What is really the point of a good webcam.
The new touchpads with click anywhere and no physical buttons are complete crap for dragging. To distinguish between moving the mouse and dragging you have to push harder. The real bad boys play fps games on a touchpad, which is very tiring on these new touchpads. Also drawing or panning in graphics or CAD design is terrible. Left hand on wasd, left thumb on the physical button, and moving the cursor with your right hand works great. What's wrong with physical buttons? Nothing! They just work, period. And that's exactly what people need.
A click anywhere touchpad is cool, and that is great for marketing, but that's it. Don't forget that a lot of CAD software uses the right or middle mouse button for panning and orbiting, because the left-click is already used for selecting and drawing. How could you do this without physical buttons? Panning around by putting 3 fingers on the touchpad? You'd have to turn off some stupid gestures first and secondly it's awkward as hell even if dragging with 3 fingers was supported by the driver.

text:
I personally have used a lenovo thinkpad yoga 460 as a school laptop for about a year now. The keyboard is the best that I have ever used on a laptop, and the screen is nice and bright, with a finish that is halfway between matte and glossy. I find myself using the nipple far more than I thought I would, and I find the stylus super-useful for drawing diagrams. I will both agree and disagree with you about fingerprint reader placement though. I think it depends on the type of reader. If it is a swipe-reader (like the one on my yoga), I would prefer it to be to the side of the trackpad (I like it where it is on the yoga, below the arrow keys), but if it is a tap-reader, it needs to be on or alongside the power button, as you say. Personally, because my thinkpad yoga has a swipe-reader, I have the palm of my hand enrolled as my index finger never seems to be reliable (probably because my fingers see a lot more wear than the palm of my hand).

As for pricing - find someone selling them brand new on ebay like I did (though YMMV - some sellers are better than others)

text:
Me wants an non buisness X1 Carbon in a 14-15 inch format, decent speakers and a dGPU (idealy a Max-Q 1050 Ti). Id compromise some build quality for lower weight (like a notebook 9), and I would accept even an Coffeelake U or Kabylake-R i3 (at max wattage) if that means the price will stay under $1200.

Asking too much right?
Oh and a 99.9Wh battery if possible.

Why cant laptops be cheaper. :c. We need another manufacturer like Xiaomi to shake the market a bit more. In my dreams I build a Laptop company together with AsRock. From there, we would become the brand of everyone, with a transparent marketing strategy, alowing the people to actually know what they are getting.

We would finally end the flashy red and black "Gaming" notebooks, the ones that some are forced to buy cause they need the horsepower for CAD or Video editing.

Devices would vary between ranges, one of them specifically oriented to offer the best hardware for you money, with some compromises.

A second one at oferring relatively low end laptops (low end cpus) but optimized for the best experience: SSD or SSHD boot drives, large capacity batteries, nice keyboards and touchpads and decent screens and speakers.

Another offering silent laptops, ideal for music production or low noise enthusiasts. Equiped with simple Y series Fanless CPUs on the low end, and super low RPM fans with large heatsinks on the high end. A third concept beeing a cooling system based on passive heatsinks placed on the back of the laptop, in where a self pumping liquid could be used for heat transfer.

Developing a universal external PCIe port, that allows the usage of much cheaper external docks for Graphics and other devices. And together with that, co developing compact laptops with powerful CPUs which unlock a higher TDP when docked to a cooling station; one that could simply use a cold plate contacting the underside of the laptop.

I have millions of ideas. I just need the contacts and a motherboard manufacturer. Nowadays I could literally 3D print prototype chassis'.

author: Jelle van M.

text:
Stormchaser Elite Dude you are absolutely wrong.
Dslr has a optical viewfinder which reduces the total light captured by the camera's sensor. Whereas there is no such thing in a mirrorless so in fact mirrorless will be able to capture a little bit more light as compared to dslr. The veiwfinders in mirrorless are electronic type, so no light is wasted in mirrorless. The only reason why dlsr is more popular today is because of the large number of lens and other gear that can go with it right now and also dslr's in the beginners range provide much more value as compared to mirrorless ones at the same range. On the top of the line though both have its own pros and cons.
author: Rayak Sil

text: Stormchaser Elite I'm sure that you didn't saw a DSLR but rather a DSLT. Sony is, as far as I know, the only one who builts DSLTs . The difference between a regular DSLR is that the mirror doesn't move. It's translucent so most of the light passes through it to the sensor and a little bit is reflected to the AF system and it has an EVF.

text: Rek1es s the mirror flips up when you take a photo, so no light is wasted because of the optical viewfinder.

text: Looked at the LG Gram 15 and the Thinkpad X1 Carbon due to them being 2.5 lbs and having 14"/15" screens.  I went with the X1 since it felt more substantial and IMO has the best keyboard period.  Price wise yeah the Lenovo Thinkpad MSRP's are a joke and buying them at full MSRP would be like buying a car for full MSRP.  Having owned a Thinkpad T40 as my first laptop I will say I actually enjoy the "nipple" and for a Thinkpad the 6th gen X1 is almost garish with it's blacked out logos and glowing "i".  The HDR display is the best but frankly not many business elites will appreciate or need it.  If you don't mind paying more for an X1 compared to a XPS 13 or your work graciously buys one for you, the Thinkpad is a thin feather light computer that offers a well built computer that will separate yourself from the XPS or Macbook users in the library or cafe.

text:
Same marketing BS I'm used to seeing from modern Lenovo. Ethernet requires an adapter, the high resolution monitor is glossy, the audio controls are hidden behind Fn key combos and the lock keys have absolutely zero visual indication of being enabled, the touchpad lacks buttons, etc. They even have flipping soldered RAM on a ThinkPad now. It's like they're aiming so hard for the "prosumer" market that they have forgotten what the actual professionals want. This is nothing more than an attempt to milk the brand.

Some of you will probably say "you're being too harsh on Lenovo, they're just adapting to the market". Again, marketing BS. I didn't commit to the ThinkPad series because they followed the trends, I did it because ThinkPads didn't follow the trends. It used to have those features consumers didn't want because it was in the way of their idea of what a laptop should look like.

For instance, the VGA port. Universally hated among gamers because it can't handle high resolutions with sharp horizontal pixels. But guess what, it always works. Always. I don't care if it's not optimal when I need to get an image from my computer to the projector wall right this second. It's hard for a projector to mess up analog RGB signals, even if one of them is missing I can still get most of the actual content out there as long as the green pin carries a sync pulse. Try that with HDMI, see how far it gets you in an environment where even the simplest of tasks can and will be done incorrectly. Oh and good luck protecting your laptop from an unshielded HDMI cable (no ground connection to equalize the charges before the differential pairs make contact), they are genuinely pure evil.

Neither is it helping that reviewers are not giving Lenovo competent enough feedback to divert them from mistakes like these. You need to put the computers in an appropriate environment, even something like a comparison with a 10 year old ThinkPad would instantly reveal half of these faults. But don't take my word for it; listen to someone like Louis Rossmann and you'll get it.

text:
If you are going to buy pre-built. You better research your stuff or have someone that knows a bit about PCs nearby. 

Many pre-builts are gimped in a certain area to keep costs down (or overcharge you), being able to spot these things can help you make the decision of if it's: A. Not that important B. Cheaply upgraded or C. Not worth the price.

Also, $2k self built would get you a decently powerful system.
author: Aeikon Devleon

text: Actually, prebuilts are a lot cheaper now due to GPU prices being surged, so I would recommend that. You can save several hundred dollars now by buying a prebuilt, but otherwise I think building your own is cheaper if things were closer to MSRP. text:
A trackpoing guy over here. I understand why people prefer touchpads over trackpoints, but hear me out:

Trackpoints have the advantage to never require to lift your hands over the trackpad when tyiping fast to do swift and short stuff, IF you internalize the motion of the trackpoint. I see it more like a tool that help to avoid much movement and keep typing and programming momentum. 

Still though, a bigger touchpad would beneficially help on gestures, that despite have having a great amount of customization, if you have big hands, just make the whole gesture part useless. But the thing is that lenovo actually tried to do so with the T440, and it was a DISASTER: the touchpad wasn't great and the trackpoint touch buttons where a mess. Tried to be a jack of all trades and became a master of none.

author: Damage42X

text:
>Thick laptops are so 2005. I'm assuming you use a thick, outdated brick phone? Same logic. Technology is advancing and having it "thin" and "powerful" is important for many of us. It's 2018. It's time to get with the times, man.

This is complete bullshit and utter crap.
- First of all, there's a thing called physics that says "you can't put a big thing in a small thing", which in normal words means, you can't put a big battery in a tiny laptop. Thicker laptop with a 20+ hours battery life or thin laptop with a 3-5 hours battery life? I'd much rather have the battery life and be able to use my fucking laptop.
- Second, that same "physic" thing says you can't put ports if the device is too thin.
If it can't have a full size ethernet and a VGA port, it's too thin. If you need to ask why VGA, you never used a laptop in a real business environment.
- Third, guess what else physics have to say? Cooling needs space. You just can't have efficient cooling when everything is crammed tight. Do I need to explain why heat is bad for your device or is that basic enough?

Thin and powerful is nice in theory. Unfortunately, it's physically impossible.
Anything that is thin and claims to be powerful is compromising everything else it can.
Can't replace/upgrade anything, or lack of ports, or tiny battery life, or cooling issue, you name it.

You want something thin? It's okay, as long as you accept that it won't be powerful. And that's mostly okay, you don't need something powerful for web browsing or average office use.

There's "going with the time", and "not being a fucking idiot".

author: Eduardo Avila

text:
Plasmaboo The word for those small laptops is: throttle. 
Those ones throttle all the time. 
Damn i compared one of those thin laptops from today (7gen i7) versus an old core2duo t9900. The old core2duo smashed, destroyed the i7 in performance! Why? Because the core2duo t9900 is a dualcore cpu with 6mb of cache and 3.06ghz. The i7 that claims to be "up to 3.1ghz" actually runs at 1.8ghz and is also dualcore. A freaking dualcore i7!!! 
This "turbo" that goes up to 3.1ghz, mostly never activates, you need to be on performance mode, connected to the outlet, cold as ice, with battery full, have turned on the laptop, hadnt any load before and even so, it will work on those lame "duty cicles" so it turns the turbo on for 2s (3.1ghz for 2 seconds) then turn of for 4s (1.8ghz for 4s) then turn on, and make this sometimes and the stick with 1.8 or maybe in some really good designed motherboards just continue with that cicle. So if you pick a game that require a old dualcore 2.2ghz processor or a dualcore 2.4ghz processor (wich old i3s, i5s, core2duos nail it, as the i5 2450m that is better basically than any i7 ulv (with u in the name) from the third to the 6gen! 

So... No! These ultrabooks and thin devices are good for browsing the web, consuming media, but when you have to do anything, like any job, any non potato compatible program, game, even an old dell 1545 is better, than, for example the asus zenbook pro or a inspiron 15r 5537 or a xps 13...  

"But what about razer blade? Bla bla bla..." Well, just search for throttle, low fps in those laptops, thousands of forums and people getting mad at it!

text: As a happy owner of a 5th gen X1 Carbon, the value proposition comes down to what kind of person you are. If you want a laptop that you can buy, and continue using for a LONG time, the X1 is a great choice. I‚Äôm a full time college student, and my tech doesn‚Äôt get treated nicely (think regular dropping on hard floors). My computer sustained virtually no physical damage, and the selection of ports are as stiff as day one. Buy a Surface laptop if you want a great computer for a few years, buy a Carbon if you want a good computer for a decade.
author: Alex LoVecchio

text: 100% agreed.  I use one in the service industry as a technician, and it has been dropped off ladders with only minor blemishes to the corners.   The 5th gen is Rock solid,  I can only hope that the 6th gen will be exactly the same build quality.
author: btw111

text: How's the battery life been? I have a surface pro 4 that (at whoppin 2 years old) is dying on me and I'm looking for a laptop that'll actually last (that's not a Mac)
author: Ivan Muchiutti

text: The battery life on the X1 is pretty impressive.  When it was new, I could easily expect 7-10hrs of battery (with standard settings), after about 4 years of heavy use and a decent amount of abuse,  I still see 5-8hrs (again, depending on use.)  My only complaint I have with mine is the necessity for the LAN adapter/dongle when using a wired network connection. As a service tech who is using the LAN connection constantly,  it's a little inconvenient, and the dongle has started to show signs of wear.  With this type of use though I can easily expect that.  That is the only complaint I can come up with about it.

text:
Here's my problem with lenovo, I don't care how "premium feeling" or "long lasting" the high end carbon series can be because realistically, very few businesses are going to buy super expensive laptops for their employees who are probably only running a few basic apps, checking their email, or browsing the web. If a business is going to provide an employee with a laptop, at most it may be a sub $800 thinkpad, and let me tell you, lenovos lower-end laptops are absolute garbage. Sure the keyboard and trackpad may not have changed much, but build quality is pretty bad and internal component and reliability wise, they are terrible. It gets worse, I expect most businesses to get the sub $400 or $500 thinkpad, and those things are horrific. I haven't even gotten to their IdeaPad lineup, there it's just embarrassing in build quality and longevity. Why am I saying this? Me and my family used to have done business with lenovo for years and we could see the quality of their laptops rapidly decrease over time. I wish tech youtubers like you would do "home or work laptop roundups" with a mediocre budget, and then compare some laptops. I know my family will not be buying a $2300 laptop for basic work.
Oh, and WHY ARE YOU COMPARING THIS TO THE DELL XPS LINEUP!!! You do realize that the Dell Latitude and Precision lineups are Dell's business lines right? Of course the missing features (SIM, Docking, ex) and the smaller price on the XPS are present, BECAUSE THE XPS IS NOT A BUSINESS LAPTOP. Don't forget about the HP Elitebooks, Probooks, and zbooks ether.

I'm still taking a T-42 to building sites every single day for onsite CAD drawing... I love the TrackPoint, love the LED above the screen, love the keyboard and used to love the battery life... I can't take away point for the battery life on a device over 10 years old. All my personal laptops' batteries kind of gave up in less then 2 years...

text: 93 degrees, huh? That's BAD .
author: Slaxbox

text:
That is how the 8th gen CPUs work. Boost until the set thermal limit set in and then adjust  its core speed to stay on that limit. The X1 have a limit of 93 degrees because that gives the most performance and the fans can be a bit more quiet. If you like some manufacturers do and set the limit on 80 degrees then the performance will suffer, sometimes as much as a whole GHz (almost 30%)  or run the fans like jet engines. I saw a test last week on the new Asus zenbook and the X1 beats it with 30% of performance with the same chip. 

That is how intel get so much performance out of the 8th gen

text:
Abion47 to me it sounded like the effect of noise reduction/suppression.  This is often enabled on business machines by default and can be disabled on the control panel, usually under "enhancements".

It basically does some algorithmic stuff to block out background ambient noise and/or office chatter.  It also makes it sound like a landline telephone call to a nokia 3510 in a pillow.

If you turned this off, the audio would probably sound fine (although with a little background noise)

author: Lumi

text: Actually my dad's work place has Kensington locks because it's really necessary that other departments can't use your laptop. So only if you bring it home with you is it not locked and then your access to the sensitive stuff is limited due to not being on the network. I have a feeling my mom's workplace is considering it but both of their work places are pretty high in security requirements across the board so it's not exactly the norm. So the department access is limited inside the company which stops un-authorized users from accessing it. BTW this is not a consumer laptop but a corporate business laptop with the required security just sold to consumers as a secondary market because my dad is getting this laptop or something similar.

text: Gary Simcox isn't it essentially just a hole in the case? Removing it for production would mean paying someone to redesign the case and going through additional testing of that revised design. Probably would cost a few thousand bucks (which isn't much, but still could be better used elsewhere). Leaving it in probably costs nothing as it doesn't appear to require any licensing fees and shouldn't really require any extra raw materials either. So why would they spend that extra money just to remove a feature? Maybe Apple would do that...but it still doesn't make much sense :)
